item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Hamas and Israel Complete 3rd Exchange of Hostages for Prisoners
item.description: Hamas released a total of 17 more hostages on Sunday, including one American — Avigail Idan, who turned 4 on Friday. The group said it was seeking to extend the truce, which is slated to continue into Monday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle carrying Israeli hostages released from Gaza late Saturday by Hamas, arriving at Sheba Medical Center near Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Fire Season in Australia Starts Early
item.description: Though experts do not think that this season will be the worst yet, they also warn that the past is no longer a reliable guide to the future.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Aaron Bunch/AAP Image, via Reuters

item.title: Need Therapy? In West Africa, Hairdressers Can Help.
item.description: An initiative to train hairdressers in mental health counseling is providing relief to hundreds of clients in a region with the world’s least access to therapy.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tele da Silveira attends to Joseline de Lima’s hair in Lomé, Togo, this month.

item.title: Battle for Influence Rages in Heart of Wagner’s Operations in Africa
item.description: The death of the mercenary group’s leader has created a window of opportunity in the Central African Republic for Western powers to offer an alternative.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

item.title: What Life in Gaza Is Like Right Now
item.description: Life in besieged Gaza revolves around a daily struggle to find food and water. With practically no fuel or coal, families are burning doors and window frames to cook what they can scrounge.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Hiba Yazbek, Abu Bakr Bashir, Ameera Harouda, Samar Abu Elouf and Yousef Masoud
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surviving has become a full-time, perilous undertaking in Gaza, with the near-total absence of crucial goods like fuel.

item.title: Despite Bans, Disabled Women Are Still Being Sterilized in Europe
item.description: Governments have declared the practice a human rights violation. But they have made exceptions that are divisive among parents, doctors and social workers.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: At age 20, Kristin Smith’s mother arranged for her to have a tubal ligation.

item.title: Cockroaches and Mountains of Trash Plague Acapulco After Hurricane
item.description: Residents complain of rashes and stomach ailments as 666,000 tons of garbage overwhelm the city. Uncollected waste after natural disasters can lead to illnesses, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Marco Ugarte/Associated Press
item.media:description: A resident walking past debris in Acapulco, Mexico, this month. The city’s mayor estimates that 666,000 tons of garbage are piled across Acapulco.

item.title: ‘It Snowballed': How a Knife Attack in Dublin Led to a Riot
item.description: The violence in Ireland’s capital on Thursday night was fueled by far-right agitators who spread rumors online about an attack on three children earlier that day.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: Riot police officers by a burning car in Dublin late Thursday.

item.title: Russia Bombards Kyiv With ‘Record’ Drone Assault, Ukraine Says
item.description: The aerial assault began early Saturday and continued past sunrise. Ukraine said its air defense teams had shot down nearly all of the explosive-laden attack drones.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspecting a damaged building and compound in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Chapter 6: Struggle and Hope
item.description: Arti passed every test for her government job but still faced disappointment and a new set of challenges.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Amanda Taub, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat, Andrea Bruce and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arti Kumari opted to study to retake India’s government job exam, this time with a newborn to care for.

item.title: Gaza Civilians, Under Israeli Barrage, Killed at Historic Pace
item.description: Even a conservative assessment of the reported Gaza casualty figures shows that the rate of death during Israel’s assault has few precedents in this century, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Argentina’s Economy Depends on the U.S. Dollar. Can Javier Milei Change That?
item.description: Years of economic quagmire created an upside-down economy in Argentina. Javier Milei, a far-right populist, won the presidency this week by promising to blow it all up.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop in Buenos Aires, where prices are often written in chalk to allow for frequent increases.

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Splits After Collapse of Unity Bid
item.description: The split over a proposed joint ticket bolsters the governing party candidate’s chances in the coming presidential election. That won’t please Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Carlos Garcia Rawlins/Reuters
item.media:description: From left to right: Terry Gou, a presidential candidate; former President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan; and Hou Yu-ih, a presidential candidate of the opposition party Kuomintang, at a meeting open to journalists in Taiwan on Thursday.

item.title: As Hamas Releases More Hostages, Longer Cease-Fire Appears Possible
item.description: A third group of captives released from Gaza included a 4-year-old dual American-Israeli citizen whose parents were killed in the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Isabel Kershner and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: People waving to Aviva Adrienne Siegel, a released hostage, aboard a bus in Ofakim, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Pro-Cease-fire Activists Shut Down Manhattan Bridge for Hours
item.description: Hundreds of protesters from Jewish Voice for Peace blocked the Manhattan entrance to the bridge, tying up traffic to and from Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Liset Cruz
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocked the Manhattan entrance of the Manhattan Bridge on Sunday as part of an action organized by Jewish Voice for Peace, which favors a lasting cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: Shooting of 3 Palestinian Men in Vermont Investigated as Possible Hate Crime
item.description: The three college students were on their way to dinner on Saturday night. The police have yet to identify a suspect.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Palestinian Father Welcomes His Imprisoned Son Back Home in the West Bank
item.description: A Palestinian prisoner freed on Sunday was paraded around his neighborhood in a 15-car motorcade after reuniting with relatives.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: Released Palestinian prisoners react from inside a vehicle after leaving Ofer military prison on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A 3rd Hamas-Israel Exchange
item.description: Plus an unusual mental health plan in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum
item.media:description: Avigail Idan, 4, was released from Gaza yesterday.

item.title: After 4-Year-Old American Girl Is Freed by Hamas, Her Family Breathes Sigh of Relief
item.description: Avigail Idan, a dual citizen of Israel and the United States, spent her fourth birthday as a captive after her parents were murdered in the Oct. 7 attack.
item.dc:creator: Anna Betts and Katherine Rosman

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the Israeli Hostages Released on Sunday
item.description: The group included several children, including a 4-year-old Israeli-American girl, and a Russian-Israeli who is the first man to be released.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Nadav Gavrielov and Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: Prime Minister Netanyahu Visits Israeli Troops in Gaza
item.description: On the third day of a pause in fighting that was expected to continue until Tuesday, Mr. Netanyahu vowed to fight on “until victory.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Israeli Government, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by the Israeli government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a visit to the Gaza Strip on Sunday.

item.title: American Girl Among Hostages Released on Sunday, Biden Says
item.description: “Thank God she’s home,” the president told reporters as he vowed to press for the release of more captives and an extension of the pause in fighting.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking in Nantucket, Mass., on Sunday.

item.title: Freed Israeli Hostages Tell Relatives of Their Time in Captivity
item.description: Two days after the first batch of hostages was released, relatives who have spoken or met with them said they seemed to have been totally cut off from the outside world.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hostages released by Hamas were brought to Sheba Medical Center near Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: American Hostage Might Be Released on Sunday, Jake Sullivan Says
item.description: Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, said there was “reason to believe” an American would be among the next Hamas captives freed in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Pro-Israeli demonstration near Central Park in New York this month.

item.title: Ukrainian Attack Cuts Power to Some Russian-Occupied Areas
item.description: The assault on energy infrastructure, a significant theater in the war, followed a large-scale Russian drone attack on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past a day care that was damaged in a Russian drone attack on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Hamas Commander for Northern Gaza Brigade Is Dead, Group Says
item.description: The group’s military wing, the Qassam Brigades, announced that Abu Anas al-Ghandour and three others had been killed. It did not say when.
item.dc:creator: Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:credit: Mahmud Hams/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fighters of the Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamas, during a parade in July.

item.title: Sierra Leone Declares National Curfew Amid Security Concerns
item.description: President Julius Maada Bio said there had been “a breach of security” at a key military barracks in the capital, Freetown.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: John Wessels/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, in June.

item.title: The pause in fighting enters a third day.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Mahmud Hams/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Palestinians leaving Gaza City on Saturday, on the second day of a truce between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Thai Mother Rejoices as Son Among Latest Hostages Released by Hamas
item.description: Watsana Yojampa spoke to her son after he was released by Hamas. There are at least 18 Thai citizens still being held hostage in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anucha Angkaew, working on an avocado farm in Israel, had earned enough to have a house built back home in Thailand. After he was kidnapped, his family feared he would never return to see it.

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Saturday
item.description: A second group of 13 included six members of an extended family.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Gaya Gupta and Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display in Tel Aviv of photos of Israeli citizens held hostage in Gaza, 13 of whom have been freed on Friday.

item.title: Unvaccinated and Vulnerable: Children Drive Surge in Deadly Outbreaks
item.description: About 60 million “zero-dose children” have not received any vaccines and have aged out of routine immunization programs. Protecting them will require a costly vaccination blitz.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Natalija Gormalova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deborah Sebi, right, a nurse at a mobile clinic in Teshie, a fishing village in Ghana, prepared an immunization for Rebecca Bamembaye’s 3-month-old, Doris.

item.title: No U.S. hostages are expected to be released in the next round, an official says.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: People held up images of Omer Neutra, an American who is being held hostage by Hamas, during a rally in Tel Aviv on Saturday night. He was serving as a soldier in the Israeli military on the border with Gaza when he was abducted.

item.title: Donors Give Over €300,000 for Immigrant Who Intervened in Dublin Stabbing
item.description: A Brazilian man stopped a stabbing that prompted one of the worst anti-immigrant riots in recent history. Many people in Ireland and beyond are saying thanks by buying him a proverbial pint.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Clodagh Kilcoyne/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard near the site of a stabbing that left several children injured in Dublin on Thursday.

item.title: Israeli Hostages and Their Families Rejoice After Release From Gaza Captivity
item.description: The return to a normal life will be a long process, doctors say.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Schneider Children's Medical Center, via Reuters
item.media:description: In this photograph released by the Schneider children’s hospital on Saturday, Aviv Asher is seen embracing his wife and children on a hospital bed.

item.title: Behind the Book Review’s Best Books List
item.description: A conversation with the editors about the painstaking process of selecting the 10 Best Books of the year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Shopping Mall Fire Kills 10 in Pakistan
item.description: Fire safety is a persistent problem in Karachi, where construction has outpaced firefighting infrastructure and building code enforcement is lax.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Akhtar Soomro/Reuters
item.media:description: A soldier stood guard after a fire at a shopping center in Karachi, Pakistan.

item.title: A Mayor Whose Past Informs His Approach to Homelessness and Addiction
item.description: Dan Carter, the mayor of Oshawa, Ontario, was a homeless addict from his teens until he was 31. Now he’s helping people who face those issues in his adopted city.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Carter, the mayor of Oshawa, Ontario, has made dealing with homelessness, addictions and mental health a priority.

item.title: Soccer Watchalongs Like Stretford Paddock Offer a Broadcast Alternative
item.description: Soccer fans are tuning out broadcasts in favor of watchalongs: streaming parties where you hear what you want to hear and see everything except the game.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Rory Smith/The New York Times
item.media:description: Watchalongs like Stretford Paddock’s have become big business, with full-scale production crews and hundreds of thousands of subscribers.

item.title: Waiting Continues for Families of American Hostages in Gaza
item.description: No Americans were released in the first day of the temporary cease-fire, but officials and families were hopeful they would be freed in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The International Committee of the Red Cross transporting released hostages from Gaza to Israel on Friday.

item.title: First Captives Freed in Tense Gaza Truce Between Israel and Hamas
item.description: Hamas freed two dozen hostages, Israel released 39 imprisoned Palestinians, and more than 130 aid trucks reached Gaza over the first day of a tense, temporary truce after seven weeks of war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Christina Goldbaum, Rami Nazzal and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: International Red Cross vehicles at the Gaza border with Egypt on Friday, said to be carrying hostages freed by Hamas.

item.title: Israelis Welcome Some Hostages Home, In a Poignant Moment
item.description: The return of 13 Israeli hostages out of more than 200 provided a glimmer of hope for a nation still traumatized by the Hamas assault of Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A helicopter with released hostages at the landing pad of Schneider hospital in Petah Tikva, Israel, on Friday.

item.title: In West Bank, Relief Over Prisoners’ Release Is Tempered by Worries About War
item.description: Families that waited outside a prison for the release of people detained by Israel said the conflict in Gaza and the rising death toll had cast a pall over any celebration.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Rami Nazzal
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the release of Palestinian prisoners outside the West Bank city of Ramallah on Friday.

item.title: 12 People Taken Hostage from Kibbutz Nir Oz Return to Israel
item.description: Of the 13 Israeli hostages released from Gaza on Friday night, 12 were from a single farming village: Kibbutz Nir Oz.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier looks inside a house that was attacked by Hamas militants on Oct. 7 in Kibbutz Nir Oz, Israel, late last month.

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the Israeli Hostages Released on Friday
item.description: The first group of 13 Israeli hostages — all women and children — were handed over to Israeli officials on Friday, joining five others released or rescued earlier in the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov, Isabel Kershner, Adam Sella, Gaya Gupta, Talya Minsberg and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display in Tel Aviv of photos of Israeli citizens held hostage in Gaza.

item.title: Audrey Salkeld, Pioneering Historian of Everest, Dies at 87
item.description: She trawled 56 boxes of forgotten archives, bringing to life mysterious figures from early expeditions on the world’s highest peak.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: The Premier League Needs a Commissioner
item.description: Allowing clubs to block rule changes and money to delay punishments feeds the perception that the same rules do not apply to everyone.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Jason Cairnduff/Action Images, via Reuters
item.media:description: The richest prize money can buy.

item.title: As Cease-Fire Takes Hold, Some Gazans Attempt a Treacherous Return Home
item.description: Israel had warned Gazans not to move from the south to the north during the cessation of hostilities, feeding their fears of permanent displacement.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians trying to return to Gaza City in the north on Friday during a pause in the conflict.

item.title: Iceland in Limbo Despite Threat of Volcanic Eruption Being Lowered
item.description: A fishing town that was evacuated this month will probably be spared, but residents can’t return until all danger has passed.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: Grindavik, Iceland, was evacuated this month because of volcanic activity.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Athlete Convicted of Murder, to Be Paroled
item.description: The South African sprinter, who garnered global headlines after killing his girlfriend in 2013, will be released in January after meeting the requirements for parole.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: John Wessels/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arriving at the Pretoria High Court in 2016. A parole board granted Mr. Pistorius’s petition for parole on the basis that he had served half of his 15-year sentence.

item.title: Past Israel-Hamas Cease-Fires Have Proved Fragile
item.description: In 2014, nine truces came and went during a 51-day conflict and more than 2,000 people were killed before there was a lasting agreement to halt the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artillery shells of the Israeli Army at the border with Gaza during the 11-day conflict between Israel and Hamas, in 2021.

item.title: For Monetochka, a Moral Stand Started a Creative Climb
item.description: Monetochka was one of Russia’s most discussed pop stars. Now, like other antiwar acts in exile, she’s having to retool her career.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Marvin Zilm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monetochka performing in Zurich this month.

item.title: Can the Palestinian Authority Really Govern Gaza After the War?
item.description: Considered authoritarian and corrupt, the Palestinian Authority is still Washington’s choice to run the enclave. But many believe it can be credible now only if it includes Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City. Hamas seized control of Gaza in 2007, after winning legislative elections the previous year.

item.title: Once a Homeless Addict, a Mayor Takes On Housing and Drug Crises
item.description: Dan Carter was on the streets for 17 years. His experience informs his policy agenda as mayor of Oshawa, Ontario, a city of 175,000 struggling with overdoses and affordability.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Dan Carter at city hall in Oshawa, Ontario. Homeless and addicted to drugs from his teenage years until he was 31, he was fired from more jobs than he could remember.

item.title: Cheers for Cricket
item.description: How sports can dissolve boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The celebration after Australia beat India to win the Cricket World Cup.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mohammed Abed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A family fleeing after an Israeli strike in Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: North Korea’s Han Kwang-song Returns to International Soccer
item.description: Han Kwang-song’s recent appearances in World Cup qualifiers were his first ones overseas since 2020, when U.N. sanctions led to an involuntary career break.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Nyein Chan Naing/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Han Kwang-song of North Korea, center, playing in a 2026 World Cup qualifier in Yangon, Myanmar, this week.

item.title: Illness Surge in China Is Not From a Novel Pathogen, Data Suggests
item.description: The W.H.O. had requested detailed information about a reported surge in respiratory illnesses in children in China. Chinese data suggested the surge was caused by known bacteria and viruses.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Children receiving intravenous drips at a hospital in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Israel, Hamas Agree to Begin Cease-Fire Friday Morning
item.description: Prodded by the U.S., Israel agreed to the pause in hostilities and the release of 150 imprisoned Palestinians in exchange for 50 hostages held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Hiba Yazbek and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alexi J. Rosenfeld/Getty Images
item.media:description: The relatives of children kidnapped on Oct. 7, along with families and supporters of hostages, protesting on Monday in Tel Aviv.
